name: Finance Basics 101
description: Master the essentials like credit scores, bank accounts, and simple debt tips.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of a credit score?
choices: To determine how much money you have in your bank account
To track your spending habits
To assess your creditworthiness for loans and credit cards
To calculate the interest rate on your savings account

questions.statement: Which of the following is a good strategy for managing credit card debt?
choices: Pay the minimum amount due each month
Use your credit card to pay off other debts
Pay off the full balance each month to avoid interest charges
Apply for more credit cards to increase your available credit

questions.statement: What is the main difference between a savings account and a checking account?
choices: A savings account earns interest, while a checking account is used for daily transactions
A checking account earns interest, while a savings account is used for daily transactions
A savings account is only for long-term goals, while a checking account can only be used in emergencies
A checking account requires a higher minimum balance than a savings account

questions.statement: What is an overdraft in a checking account?
choices: A fee charged for using an ATM
A feature that allows you to spend more money than you have in your account, typically with a fee
A penalty for not maintaining a minimum balance
An automatic transfer from your savings account to cover expenses

questions.statement: Which of the following is a benefit of setting financial goals?
choices: It ensures you never have to borrow money
It helps you prioritize spending and saving, making it easier to manage your finances
It guarantees a higher income
It eliminates the need for a budget

name: Investor in Training
description: Learn the ropes of investing with concepts like diversification and mutual funds.

questions.statement: What does the term 'diversification' mean in investing?
choices: Investing all your money in one stock to maximize returns
Spreading your investments across different asset types to reduce risk
Only investing in government bonds
Using your savings to start a business

questions.statement: Which of the following best describes a 'mutual fund'?
choices: A type of bank account with a fixed interest rate
A pooled investment vehicle managed by professionals that invests in a diversified portfolio of assets
A savings account with high returns
A loan taken out for purchasing a house

questions.statement: What is the 'time value of money'?
choices: The concept that money saved today is worth less in the future due to inflation
The idea that money available now is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its earning potential
The amount of time it takes for your money to double in a savings account
The time it takes to repay a loan
A government savings bond
A type of retirement savings plan offered by employers, where employees can contribute a portion of their salary
A savings account for medical expenses
A high-interest checking account

questions.statement: Which of the following statements is true about bonds?
choices: Bonds are a form of equity ownership in a company
Bonds typically offer lower risk but also lower returns compared to stocks
Bonds guarantee higher returns than any other investment
Bonds do not have a maturity date

name: Financial Pro Moves
description: Head deep into advanced topics like compound interest, emergency funds, and portfolio strategy.

questions.statement: What is the purpose of an emergency fund?
choices: To cover regular monthly expenses
To have funds available for unexpected expenses, such as medical emergencies or car repairs
To save for a vacation
To invest in the stock market
Interest earned only on the initial amount of money saved
Interest calculated on both the initial principal and the accumulated interest from previous periods
Interest that decreases over time
Interest that only applies to loans and credit cards

questions.statement: How does inflation impact purchasing power?
choices: It increases the value of money over time
It decreases the value of money, making goods and services more expensive
It has no impact on purchasing power
It stabilizes the prices of goods and services

questions.statement: What is dollar-cost averaging in investing?
choices: Investing a large sum of money all at once to capitalize on market trends
Regularly investing a fixed amount of money, regardless of market conditions, to reduce the impact of market volatility
Only investing when the market is at its lowest point
Selling all investments when the market declines

questions.statement: What does it mean to 'rebalance' an investment portfolio?
choices: Selling all assets in the portfolio to start over
Adjusting the asset allocation in your portfolio to maintain your desired level of risk
Switching all investments to bonds to reduce risk
Buying more stocks to increase potential returns
